title: When will the 7-day rolling average of confirmed cases of COVID-19 in New York City (NYC) next reach or exceed 1,500?
preds: As of 11/30, the rolling average is achieved on 11/22 at 1,500 (which may be more after lagging cases are reported).
Officially crossed the threshold on 11/22 per the most recent update to NYC's DOH website.

Updating on deceleration in cases.
I also think that the numbers will really jump up before Thanksgiving, because many people will test ahead of trips to relatives, however, past-26 will really slow down, because people will delay testing till after Thanksgiving, and Nov 30 will not capture of these delayed tests.

@SE_Meyer - I have some numbers on paper, there are going up, but (after this single data point), anything after a week was single digit growth, but it is creeping up, I'll update as they change tomorrow and we will see what the early numbers for the 23rd will show. While, this will creep the values for the last 2 weeks of Nov, it doesn't change the underlying premise of my skepticism of a resolution in November. This week, the people will be less likely to report, probably until Monday the 30th, because it's a holiday weekend and we are a stubborn bunch.
the site we're using for the "data" is a little slow and unreliable, so hedging 10%

Crowd seems pretty convinced this is going over this month, and unless the NYC Health department change their counting criteria it's more like a 50-50, this week will show some growth, but it depends when the spike in cases associated with Thanksgiving starts to come through in the numbers. Why is it 50-50?   - John Hopkins for the counties of New York, Richmond, Bronx, Kings and Queens (which to this non-American seem to correspond with the 5 boroughs?) has reported 18,515 cases between 11/11 - 21/11 (1) compared to NYC  Health's count of 13,549. The biggest discrepancy I can see is for 21/11: 2021 VS 543. - A 7 day average makes it difficult for the 1,500 number to definitely be exceeded before December. Weekends are underreported, so assuming the 22/11 numbers are 400-600 the 7 day average drops below 1,100 cases. This leaves between 9000-9500 cases reported between the 23rd and the 27th, before the numbers drop off again for the weekend (1800-1900/per day), as none of the previous 7 days exceeds 1,500.  If we see the reported number for the 22/11 above 800, I will adjust heavily to this month, but not until then. 1. https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/us-map

From the UK with little-to-be-proud-of, but have to say the time it takes NYC Gov to collect, publish and update data is just unbelievable, 7-day average cases exceeded 1,500 days ago ... hardly dealing with millions of cases here. This regardless of the counting argument between NY State and NYC.
If not on 16 November 2020, then on 18 November at the very latest.

Adjusting to 100% because:
1) All trending in the "complete" part of the chart is consistent with exceeding 1500 (predictable linear growth)
2) Trending continues for the first few days of "incomplete" part of the chart, which is an indication that the growh is actually accelerating
Interesting that one of the hotspot neighborhoods is Corona/North Corona.
NYT reporting average 1,673 daily cases last week, only the lag stopping this being resolved.
Even if cases growth arithmetically rather than exponentially, we'll be there.
uppping, liked @SE_Meyer logic on the cases getting updated retroactively

It got as high as 1000 a few days ago and has ticked down slightly to above 900: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page Yesterday I spoke to an MD/PhdD pathologist at a new york hospital and his view is that this is going to be bad, it will continue to get bad quicikly, and that it will actually be worse than the spring because it will be harder to change behavior and its so widespread. The Oliver Wyman pandemic navigator has the cases at about 2200 by December 1: https://pandemicnavigator.oliverwyman.com/forecast?mode=counties&region=US_US-NY_005&panel=baseline All of this would basically skew the probabilities to something like 80%. The thing that is tempering it down a bit for me is (a) not understanding the recent (albeit small) downtick in NYC; (b) some potential funkiness regarding testing and total number of cases around thanksgiving. That said, we could easily hit 1500 cases BEFORE

It got as high as 1000 a few days ago and has ticked down slightly to above 900: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page Yesterday I spoke to an MD/PhdD pathologist at a new york hospital and his view is that this is going to be bad, it will continue to get bad quicikly, and that it will actually be worse than the spring because it will be harder to change behavior and its so widespread. The Oliver Wyman pandemic navigator has the cases at about 2200 by December 1: https://pandemicnavigator.oliverwyman.com/forecast?mode=counties&region=US_US-NY_005&panel=baseline All of this would basically skew the probabilities to something like 80%. The thing that is tempering it down a bit for me is (a) not understanding the recent (albeit small) downtick in NYC; (b) some potential funkiness regarding testing and total number of cases around thanksgiving. That said, we could easily hit 1500 cases BEFORE
Only halfway through the month and they are already trending over 900 daily.
7-day rolling average of cases is increasing ~ 300/week. Likely to cross 1500/day before the end of November.

Purely based on projection of virus, pretty high likelihood that we are there by Dec 1. However, thanksgiving falls in the 7 day window and I wonder if you just get many fewer tests during that period.
16 November 2020 (with data completed, announced around 23 Nov) or a couple of days later.
starting late. i think it'll finish early.
The main thing I’m learning from these types of challenges: never bet against Covid.
As of yesterday's update, the 7-day rolling average for cases reached 750 on 7 Nov. The steady increase continues. https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page

This is hard to gauge because there is no base case. Emergency room visits are not increasing, so this appears to be a testing phenomenon and not an actual second wave. The PCR tests are well known to be extremely oversensitive giving many false positives. Every time you have a false positive then you have to test everyone in that person's contact list, giving you more possible false positives. The R naught of the test is greater than the R naught of the virus. again, I'm basing this on the fact that emergency room visits are not increasing. it could be simply that the virus is moving through a different segment of the population, a younger segment that does not have symptoms when they are positive... which again is questionable whether that should be treated as a positive case. so this arc is not going to follow the same arc of the original outbreak.
Looking like the rate is probably too slow for this month, if it continues to increase it could hit next month, but could be any time.

Oliver Wyman Pandemic navigator has been a pretty reliable forecast, has cases at 1350 by end of month.  https://pandemicnavigator.oliverwyman.com/forecast?mode=counties&region=US_US-NY_005&panel=baseline

There tends to be a lag in reporting on the NYC website, but according to the NYT, there have been >1,000 cases reported each of the last 4 days (Saturday's figures were a 68% increase over the past two weeks).  https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/09/nyregion/nyc-virus-spike.html
7 day average actually ticked down, though positivity rate is higher. Warm weather should blunt the spread a little, revising forecast

Oliver Whman model projects 7 day case average at 1200 by end of November, increasing 50% month on month. It’s a top 5 global forecast model (and my former employer, they are generally very good on this kind of thing).
Up to 600 daily average from 260, still skeptical this is going to take off.

I still think NYC has herd immunity. They aren't climbing when the rest of the country is. The data is clear; masks and lockdowns gave no effect on the virus, so what they do in that regard doesn't matter.
Weighting more toward holidays and not before February, so far they seem to have contained this wave and Thanksgiving effects wouldn't show up until December.

Adjusting forecast... despite the nation seeing a significant spike in cases, NY's 7-day average isnt spiking.  Lots of social interaction around Halloween, Election Day, and Thanksgiving may change that, but it is looking more like NYC has reasonable protocols that people are following to avoid the national spike.

https://www.dailyfreeman.com/news/national/virus-hospitalizations-reach-1-000-in-ny-highest-since-june/article_af8861e7-e5e8-55fc-84d7-098c09c864a2.html
Toward the bottom of this story, we learn that there were about 1600 new cases statewide yesterday, but from the NYC stats it looks like maybe 400 were from the city.  That's about 25% of statewide cases, while the city has about 40% of the statewide population.  I had to dig up an envelope so I could do the estimates on the back of one, but it looks like the city won't see 1k new cases until some time in December at the earliest.  This is, however, very rough and so likely wrong.
Flu season/winter months as well as quarantine fatigue will cause a spike in late fall/early winter

https://www.google.com/amp/s/nypost.com/2020/10/21/gov-cuomo-loosens-covid-19-restrictions-in-some-nyc-hot-spots/amp/ They have handled it much better than other states that aren't so densely populated.

Recent measures taken to curb clusters in NYC appear to be successful, showing the city's response had a meaningful impact. Upcoming holiday gatherings and travel pose major risks, however it will take at least a few weeks to see the impact of that, and summer holidays did not lead to large spikes in cases. However, those were much more likely to be celebrated outdoors compared to fall/winter holidays, which needs to be considered. Assuming the virus first arrived in NYC in very late 2019/early 2020, and cases peaked in March/April (with no protective measures like mask wearing in place), I'd assume it would also take us a while us to see case levels reach 1,500/day again even if our efforts to contain the virus in the winter are not very successful. That's why I believe there's a 50% chance we will not hit 1,500 before Feb 2021.

It's down 300 and is trending down. So I'll cross out November and even December. But I can't imagine Thanksgiving, winter and Christmas celebrations not driving a 5X increase in cases from the current bottom.  Also, November-ish the 6 month immunity of the ones who got it in Spring is likely to wane.  Lockdowns though may prevent  the revival.

Current averages are well below 1k per day and look to be steady.  Next risk points are thanksgiving and the election, so if they do cause problems infections will increase 1 to 2 weeks later, and would go exponentially more another few weeks later.  So unlikely before December. But possible in December and post Christmas.
Looks like the rate of increase would most likely be too low to exceed this month, -4 to that category.
Misunderstood the question on my first attempt !

The 7 day average is currently well below 1000 but with the coming of the flu season and the holiday travel season, I assess an increase in cases.  Given the delay in reporting, I suspect we'll see a spike a week after Thanksgiving and a spike a week after Christmas and New years.  A vaccine may help hold back large spikes but 1500 is well within a reasonable spike as large populations travel for the holidays.
I believe when the weather turns colder, infection rate will rise.

A combination of schools opening, indoor dining at restaurants, people getting more confident with low case counts, cold and flu season, thanksgiving holiday, all added to Christmas/holiday shopping activity (all our traditional holiday events have been cancelled, I suspect people will seek to gather at home even more now) are a recipe to at least double the current rates.  (1,500 is close to doubling our averages now). Yes, the city is responding quickly to clusters and outbreaks but with budget issues, once those outbreaks are more widespread, it won't be so easy.

https://newyork.cbslocal.com/2020/10/11/court-upholds-gov-cuomos-restrictions-on-houses-of-worship-in-covid-19-hot-spots/ The authorities seem to be doing a good job in containing the spread. Reducing the probability of an early sharp jump in cases
New York state is the state that has best controlled the spread of the virus. New York City will never see 1,500 cases in a day before 1 Feb 2021.

Flatline for three months. New York City appears to have developed a kind of herd immunity.  The number of cases in New York has now been flatlined for half of the time that the virus has even been in the city.

The numbers currently are low hovering in the 500-700 range in the past week however just to get a sense of the base rate compared NYC to Quebec, Canada which is seeing a spike now. (interestingly both have the same population of around 8.5mn people). Montreal has about 4.2mn people (spread over 432 sqkm) while NYC has 8.7mn(spread over 784sq km). So Roughly 15% higher population density. Montreal has had around 280 cases yesterday  https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/quebec-covid-19-cases-surpass-85-000-14-more-deaths-1.5140800 Expect to see something similar playing out in NYC as well.  With the fall season approaching expect numbers to rise steadily with upcoming festive season.

Looking at the NYC data, it took about a month to fall from 1500 rolling average to 500.  However, that was in the midst of weighty social shutdown.  Cooler temps will make outdoor dining less attractive to NYC residents, perhaps driving them to indoor dining.  Unless indoor social activities are completely shut down, we should see a gradual peak before Jan 31st.

Current averages are close to 500/day. Even with an increase with schools back in person, some people back to work, and kids sports the likelihood of hitting 1,500/d is low in October. Not sure that Halloween will be a big factor with many choosing to not participate. Thanksgiving, Hanukaka (12/10), Christmas, and New Years Eve will likely impact the case count. NYC has been shutting down in select areas in response to the increases in local rates. The results will lag, but the chance of exceeding 1,500 increases in January. It remains to be seen how effective the mayor's response will be.

NYC is at about 400-500 cases per day and has been since June 2020. There maybe has been a little spike recently, but not much. It's hard to see it spiking so much in the short time frame for this first bin. It's definitely possible for a lot of the later ones, but hard to anticipate. Given how well NYC has done, it seems like it's definitely possible it will last.
The count has been flatline for the last three months. I see no reason for it to pick up. I think New York has pretty close to herd immunity.

Uncertain, leaning slightly toward post Christmas/New Year spike or just not hitting that number at all. NYC has been estimated at about 20% seroprevalence which I think is playing a role in keeping their numbers down. But 20% still isn't that much and leaves plenty of room for cases to jump. Unlikely for a vaccine to have much effect in the time period. And always the possibility that a data revision before March changes it to hit the peak in one of the earlier months.
